summary: This is a Bureau of Justice Statistics report titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2019' analyzing data from the National Crime Victimization Survey. It presents statistical trends in violent and property crime in the United States from 2015-2019, noting a significant decrease in violent crime excluding simple assault from 2018 to 2019. The document contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or related events. This document is a Bureau of Justice Statistics report titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2019,' published in September 2020. It presents comparative crime statistics from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) and the FBI's Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) program for 2018 and 2019, analyzing trends in reported and unreported crime, victim demographics, and reporting rates to police. It contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or related events. This document is a Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) report titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2019' that details new methodological classifications for urban, suburban, and rural areas in the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS). It explains the shortcomings of the old definitions and presents new criteria based on population density and weighted housing-unit density, comparing crime victimization rates under both classification systems for 2018 and 2019. This document is a statistical report from the Bureau of Justice Statistics titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', presenting data from the National Crime Victimization Survey. It analyzes violent and property crime incidents, victim and offender demographics, and prevalence rates for 2019, with comparisons to previous years. It contains no specific information about the Epstein case. This document is a statistical report titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2019' published by the Bureau of Justice Statistics in September 2020. It presents data from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) for 2015-2019, focusing on property and violent crime prevalence, reporting rates, and demographic breakdowns. It is not a document directly related to the Epstein case but appears to be part of a larger document collection. This document is a statistical report from the Bureau of Justice Statistics titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', detailing methodology, survey coverage, and data analysis for the National Crime Victimization Survey. It contains no direct information about the Epstein case, individuals, or events related to it. This document is a statistical appendix from the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) report 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', detailing methodology, standard error calculations, and data tables for the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS). It explains the survey's measurement of rape and sexual assault and provides extensive statistical tables on victimization rates from 1993 to 2019. This document is an appendix section from the Bureau of Justice Statistics report 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', containing detailed standard error tables for crime victimization statistics from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) for 2018 and 2019. It provides statistical data on rates, percentages, and numbers of various crimes, including violent crime, rape/sexual assault, robbery, and property crime, broken down by demographic characteristics. This document is a statistical appendix from the Bureau of Justice Statistics report 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', containing demographic tables and urban area classifications. It is not a primary Epstein case document but appears to have been included in a larger document set, possibly as supporting material or due to a filing error.

keyFacts: This document is a general U.S. crime statistics report from September 2020 and contains no information specific to the Jeffrey Epstein case.
The report analyzes data from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) covering 2015-2019.
It notes a statistically significant 15% decrease in the rate of violent crime excluding simple assault from 2018 to 2019.
The report highlights a decline in rape or sexual assault victimizations from 2.7 per 1,000 persons in 2018 to 1.7 per 1,000 in 2019.
The burglary rate in 2019 was reported as the lowest since the NCVS survey was redesigned in 1993.
This document is a general U.S. crime statistics report (Criminal Victimization, 2019) from the Bureau of Justice Statistics, dated September 2020.
It compares data from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) and the FBI's Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) program for 2018 and 2019.
Key findings include that about 41% of violent victimizations were reported to police in 2019, and the rate of unreported violent crime increased from 2015 to 2019.
The report analyzes crime reporting rates by demographic characteristics such as sex, race, age, and household income.
The document contains no information, names, or events related to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or his criminal case.

The Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) introduced new definitions for classifying urban, suburban, and rural areas in the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) to address inaccuracies in the old county-based MSA system.

The new urban definition is based on criteria including being the main city in a large urbanized area with high weighted housing-unit density, or having a high population and density threshold (e.g., 50,000 population with 5,000 housing units/sq mi).

Under the new definitions, 12% of the U.S. population lives in urban areas, 69% in suburban areas, and 19% in rural areas, a significant shift from the old definitions (33% urban, 53% suburban, 14% rural).

In 2019, based on the new classifications, the rate of violent victimization declined in urban areas from 2018, but showed no significant change in suburban or rural areas; property crime rates declined in suburban and rural areas.

The report compares classification results with the American Housing Survey (AHS), finding the new NCVS definitions align much more closely with residents' own perceptions of where they live than the old definitions did.
This document is a general statistical report on U.S. criminal victimization for 2019 and contains no information related to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or his case.
The data is sourced from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) conducted by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
The report details demographic patterns of violent crime victims and offenders based on victims' perceptions.
It notes a decline from 2018 to 2019 in the percentage of persons who were victims of violent crime excluding simple assault, largely driven by a decrease in rape or sexual assault.
The percentage of households that experienced property crime decreased from 2018 to 2019.
This document is a Bureau of Justice Statistics report on national crime victimization trends from 2015-2019, not a direct Epstein case document.
The report shows a 19% drop in serious crime victims from 2018 to 2019, from 4.6 million to 3.8 million persons.
The percentage of persons age 12 or older who were victims of completed or attempted rape or sexual assault with injury/force declined from 0.09% in 2018 to 0.06% in 2019.
In 2019, 40.9% of violent victimizations were reported to police, a decrease from previous years.

It details the methodology of the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS), including survey coverage, measurement of crime, and weighting adjustments.
The text includes statistical tables analyzing violent incidents by victim and offender race/ethnicity.
There is no mention of Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, victims, or any related legal proceedings.

The document is a methodological appendix and data tables from the BJS report 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', published in September 2020.
It details the NCVS's two-stage measurement approach for identifying rape and sexual assault victimization, including specific screening questions and classification criteria.

The report explains the use of Balanced Repeated Replication (BRR) with Fay's method for calculating standard errors for key estimates, a change from prior years which used Generalized Variance Function (GVF) parameters.
Extensive statistical tables present estimates and standard errors for violent and property crime victimization rates from 1993 through 2019.
The document notes a revised 2016 NCVS data file was created due to a sample size increase and adjustment to reflect the 2010 census, which affected year-to-year comparisons.
The document is a statistical appendix from the Bureau of Justice Statistics report 'Criminal Victimization, 2019', dated September 2020.
It presents standard error calculations for crime victimization data from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS) for 2018 and 2019.
The data covers various crime types including violent crime, rape/sexual assault, robbery, aggravated assault, and property crime.
Statistics are broken down by numerous victim demographics including sex, race/ethnicity, age, marital status, household income, and location of residence.
The document notes a correction was made for a coding error that affected earlier estimates published in the 2018 report.
